Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction into fuels has been an attractive research topic.Herein, Ag and TiO 2 nanoparticles co-loaded zeolite TS-1 (Ag-TiO 2 TS-1) were synthesized by the ion-exchange and subsequently in-situ photodeposition method.The obtained Ag-TiO 2 TS-1 sample has a high surface area and rich Ti 3 -V o defects and as well as highly dispersed Ag nanoparticles.As expected, the sample Ag-TiO 2 TS-1 not only shows high CO 2 adsorption capacity, but also improves the separation efficiency of

to realize the separation of photogenerated charges; 2) Ag nanoparticles on the support can rapidly capture photogenerated electrons from the TiO 2 .In the process of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction, the highly exposed planes 101 planes of TiO 2 and Ag nanoparticles as active sites also reduce CO 2 into CO or CH 4 (Step II).In the photocatalytic CO 2 conversion, Ag acts as a cocatalyst not only improve the visible light absorption performance and photoelectric properties, but also induce the efficient

but also induce the efficient separation of photogenerated electrons and holes.More importantly, more hot electrons are generated in metal Ag due to SPR effect (route B).Next, the hot plasmonic electrons in Ag nanoparticles can transfer to the TiO 2 nanoparticles or even are trapped by Ag, These electrons on the TiO 2 and Ag nanoparticles further react with CO 2 to produce CO or CH 4 under photoreduction reaction.The sample Ag-TiO 2 TS-1 shows super performance of CO 2 reduction activity compared with the

technique to obtain catalyst slurry.Next, 0.3 mL slurry was coated on FTO glass plate with an active area of 1 cm 2 , followed by drying at 100 C for 4 h. Sun et al. mL gas-closed system and the light source was a 300 W Xe lamp.Typically, 0.3 mL slurry was coated on FTO glass plate with an active area of 1 cm 2 .Prior to irradiation, the photoreaction system was purged with the high-purity N 2 for 30 min to remove air and then purged with

remove air and then purged with CO 2 gas for 30 min.Next, 1 mL distilled water was injected into the photoreaction system and initiated the photocatalytic reaction.The reduction products were collected at given intervals (1 h) and determined by a gas chromatography (Thermo Scientific TRACE 1300) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The apparent quantum efficiency (QE) was measured under the same photocatalytic reaction condition with irradiation light

the separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs.As a result, only CO and CH 4 can be detected on the sample Ag-TiO 2 TS-1 in the photocatalytic CO 2 conversion, and the competing H 2 evolution can be completely suppressed, suggestive of its high selectivity.The super photocatalytic activity toward CO 2 reduction can be ascribed to the synergistic effect among highly dispersed Ag nanoparticle, the support zeolite TS-1 and TiO 2 with highly exposed 101 planes.

Tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 25 wt) was purchased from Shanghai JK, China.Silicic acid hydrate(H 2 SiO 3 , CR), titanium sulfate (Ti(SO 4 ) 2 , CR), sodium carbonate (Na 2 CO 3 , CR), PVP (K-40), glycol, methyl alcohol (CH 3 OH) and silver nitrate (AgNO 3 , CR) were provided from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd without further purification in this work. were performed on the CHI 660A electrochemical workstation with three electrode system, and Na 2 SO 4 (0.5 M) was used as electrolyte.A 300 W Xe lamp was employed as the light source.Pt sheet and AgAgCl were the opposite electrode and reference electrode, respectively.For preparing the work electrode, 40 mg catalyst and 10 mg carbon were ground and then dispersed into the mixed solution including 1 mL ethanol, 0.5 mL water and 0.2 mL Nafion solution (5) by ultrasonic technique to obtain catalyst

remove air and then purged with CO 2 gas for 30 min.Next, 1 mL distilled water was injected into the photoreaction system and initiated the photocatalytic reaction.The reduction products were collected at given intervals (1 h) and determined by a gas chromatography (Thermo Scientific TRACE 1300) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The apparent quantum efficiency (QE) was measured under the same photocatalytic reaction condition with irradiation light

The adsorption and transport of reactant on the catalyst are also crucial to accelerate the photoconversion of CO 2 , thus the surface area and pore size distribution of the samples are studied, as shown in Fig. 4a andb, and the corresponding pore structure parameters are listed in Table 1.All presented samples exhibit typical type I and IV isotherms, indicating the existence of microporous and mesoporous structure, respectively.The support TS-1 shows a higher BET surface area (327 m 2 g -1 ) and a larger

the separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs.As a result, only CO and CH 4 can be detected on the sample Ag-TiO 2 TS-1 in the photocatalytic CO 2 conversion, and the competing H 2 evolution can be completely suppressed, suggestive of its high selectivity.The super photocatalytic activity toward CO 2 reduction can be ascribed to the synergistic effect among highly dispersed Ag nanoparticle, the support zeolite TS-1 and TiO 2 with highly exposed 101 planes.
